[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Views.cs] [Function: IsTokenAvailableForMethodFee() private] [IsBurnable Only] Relying solely on tokenInfo.IsBurnable means any burnable token can pay method fees - can this allow attacker-created burnable tokens with zero value to be used for fee payment, bypassing economic security? (Critical)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Views.cs] [Function: GetReservedExternalInfoKeyList()] [Hardcoded Keys] GetReservedExternalInfoKeyList() returns hardcoded external info keys from TokenContractConstants - can these keys be bypassed if external info validation doesn't properly restrict using reserved keys? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Views.cs] [Function: GetReservedExternalInfoKeyList()] [Key Collision] If user-provided external info keys collide with LockCallbackExternalInfoKey, LogEventExternalInfoKey, TransferCallbackExternalInfoKey, or UnlockCallbackExternalInfoKey, can this cause callback/logging mechanisms to malfunction? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Views.cs] [Function: IsAddressInCreateWhiteList()] [Whitelist Logic] IsAddressInCreateWhiteList() allows zero smart contract, parliament controller, economic contract, and cross-chain contract - can one of these whitelisted addresses be compromised to bypass create restrictions? (Critical)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Views.cs] [Function: IsAddressInCreateWhiteList()] [GetDefaultParliamentController] The function calls GetDefaultParliamentController().OwnerAddress - if parliament controller is manipulated, can attacker addresses become whitelisted for token creation? (Critical)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Views.cs] [Function: IsAddressInCreateWhiteList()] [System Contract Names] The function uses SmartContractConstants.EconomicContractSystemName and CrossChainContractSystemName - if these system contract addresses change or are maliciously registered, can IsAddressInCreateWhiteList() incorrectly whitelist attacker contracts? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Views.cs] [Function: GetTokenAlias()] [Collection Symbol Resolution] GetTokenAlias() calls GetNftCollectionSymbol(input.Value, true) - if this doesn't properly validate NFT vs non-NFT symbols, can it return incorrect collection symbols causing wrong alias lookups? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Views.cs] [Function: GetTokenAlias()] [ExtractAliasSetting] The function calls ExtractAliasSetting(tokenInfo) and discards the first returned value - is the discarded value security-relevant, and can extracting only alias cause incomplete validation? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Views.cs] [Function: GetTokenAlias()] [Null TokenInfo] If GetTokenInfo(collectionSymbol) returns null, does ExtractAliasSetting handle null input gracefully, or can it cause null reference exceptions? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Views.cs] [Function: GetSymbolByAlias()] [Alias Resolution] GetSymbolByAlias() returns GetActualTokenSymbol(input.Value) wrapped in StringValue - if alias mappings are inconsistent, can this return symbols that don't match the user's intent? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Views.cs] [Function: GetSymbolByAlias()] [Null Input] Does GetSymbolByAlias() validate input.Value is non-null before calling GetActualTokenSymbol(), or can null aliases cause unexpected behavior? (Low)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Views.cs] [Function: GetActualTokenSymbol()] [Null Coalescing] GetActualTokenSymbol() uses null coalescing operator to return State.SymbolAliasMap[aliasOrSymbol] ?? aliasOrSymbol if State.TokenInfos[aliasOrSymbol] is null - can this logic incorrectly return aliasOrSymbol when it's actually an invalid symbol? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Views.cs] [Function: GetActualTokenSymbol()] [Alias Priority] The function prioritizes direct symbol lookup (State.TokenInfos) over alias mapping - can this be exploited if a symbol and an alias have the same name, causing ambiguity in which token is actually referenced? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Views.cs] [Function: GetActualTokenSymbol()] [Unregistered Alias] If State.SymbolAliasMap[aliasOrSymbol] returns null and State.TokenInfos[aliasOrSymbol] is also null, GetActualTokenSymbol() returns the input unchanged - can this cause operations to proceed with invalid symbols? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Views.cs] [Function: IsInTransferBlackList()] [Blacklist Scope] IsInTransferBlackList() checks State.TransferBlackList[input] - does this blacklist apply to all token types, or can it be bypassed by transferring specific token symbols that aren't covered? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.MultiToken/TokenContract_Views.cs] [Function: IsInTransferBlackList()] [Address Validation] Does IsInTransferBlackList() validate that input is a valid address before lookup, or can null/zero addresses return misleading blacklist status? (Low)
